channels.name: Langs that compile to JS
channels.laspost: I'm surprised nobody has mentioned Haxe. It has a real type system because the compiler is written in OCaml. The abstractions it uses are zero cost and the Javascript it generates is human readable. It has seamless integration with Javascript. The neatest part? You can compile the Haxe code you wrote in C, Java, or hell even PHP! You have the advantage of only writing the code once for both the front and back end without ever touching NodeJS.>>>/lambda/30385

feeds.title: [thread update] /yn/
feeds.content: R: 300 / I: 66 (sticky)                                                        General help threadhere we post "WHY IS THIS NOT WORKING" and then someone else posts "THIS IS WHY AND HOW TO FIX" yayhelping the YN/fangame community, ONE HELP THREAD AT A TIME.Previously solved problemsWHEN USING WINE:Error80004001add LC_ALL=ja_JP@utf8 before the line to execute wine on your terminal.I downloaded an old version of YN that still has everything written in japanese, save the game text, and it's never given me any errors. If anyone wants me to post this on /media/ i can but, i trust saya-chan's repack more than this half-translated thing lol. especially since i played it on an XP.

feeds.title: [thread update] /tech/ lain
feeds.content: R: 167 / I: 7                                                          Rust Thread>inb4 tranny language not gonna botherWhy is there no Rust thread yet? I have taught it myself after Go and to me it feels like it allows me to write concurrent code much easier and giving me more control over how I wanna implement it (threads, channels or async). The learning resources also feel like the best I've ever dealt with, there's an official learning book, there's "Rust by example", the standard library docs always provide examples too and there's a million more good things I can say about it. Up until now I haven't ran into any significant problems with the language unlike Go (https://fasterthanli.me/articles/i-want-off-mr-golangs-wild-ride) and I think in the future it will entirely replace C++. Has lainon tried Rust yet?

feeds.title: [thread update] /tech/ lain
feeds.content: R: 13 / I: 0                                                          Langs that compile to JSOn my job i have to work quite a bit with javascript. Js let's you do some functional shanenigans but sometimes it get's in the way, Also the lack of a real type system leads to a lot of time debugging. I used to like typescript till i tried ReScript (https://rescript-lang.org/try)  a bit. It's type system is far better than typescript BS and the lang itself is clear enough with a neat pack of features. It compiles to JS so i don't get in trouble. So far is a bit rough in the edges but i quite like it. Do someone has a better option or have a similar experience? Let's share

feeds.title: [thread update]   Langs that compile to JS
feeds.content: >>32244Javascript is bad, but thinking pure HTML and CSS could replace most of the stuff we have is absolutely delusional.The web was made from the start to read text and images, as soon as we started to make basically applications out of it we should had rewritten how html and css works, now its basically a point of no return and js is sadly essential.

feeds.content: R: 0 / I: 0                                                          Legacy CodeI'm starting a new programming project which involves Legacy code and I'm wondering if any Alices here are able to share there wisdom when it comes to this sort of stuff.Biggest pains in my neck:-It being difficult to find relevant documentation for old proprietary libraries-Coping with having 32 bit dependencies on a 64 bit computer-Obtaining the necessary disk software and/or obtaining keys for themI'm wondering if there's any hacks for these issues that I'm completely clueless about.

feeds.title: [thread update]   Langs that compile to JS
feeds.content: I'm surprised nobody has mentioned Haxe. It has a real type system because the compiler is written in OCaml. The abstractions it uses are zero cost and the Javascript it generates is human readable. It has seamless integration with Javascript. The neatest part? You can compile the Haxe code you wrote in C, Java, or hell even PHP! You have the advantage of only writing the code once for both the front and back end without ever touching NodeJS.>>>/lambda/30385

feeds.title: [thread update] /v/
feeds.content: Most open world games are antithetical to adventure, actual adventures and the stories they inspire tend to have a sense of "whoops you're fucked now guess you'll have to deal with it for a while now" to them. For example here are things you would see on an adventure:>getting captured and forced into servitude as a gladiator for days with no obvious means of escape>working off a debt to pirates on a dock and risking having a bounty if you escape without paying in full>being blocked from entering a city due to a quarantine camp being set up outside for infected refugees>getting jailed on suspicions of being a spy crossing borders due to an ongoing war in the region>being invited to perform with a troupe touring towns and drinking and sleeping with them in inns or camps>being stuck in a town/port and having to secure a carriage/boat to your next destination You see none of that in open world games because it would "take away freedom from the players" and instead of trying to think of creative designed ways to add freedom like how New Vegas gives you various ways of entering Vegas which was great, they just don't bother with scenarios like these at all. They're good even when they're completely railroaded like having to close the Oblivion gate to enter Kvatch, as long as you're stuck in a certain place with a problem that makes you think "whew glad that's over" when it's finished.Most of the time in open world games problems like these would have jarring solutions like letting the player simply kill everyone, or hop over a wall, or pay off everything with their gigantic treasure hoards they carry around everywhere in their pockets and that they gained by selling goblin armor. Open world games are too limited by having to cater to normalfags who hate being restricted or forced to be creative and who want to be demigods who are never inconvenienced, and for that reason they'll never be a true adventure or a world and will feel like a trivial child's playbox.
